<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
WORKFORCE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/21/facebook-joins-accelerating-trend-toward-permanent-remote-work?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Grandma, What’s a Commute?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Home office" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC85MzMvaG9tZV9vZmZpY2UuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">One day, you might compare working in an office to remembering someone's phone number—something you don't have to do anymore. Yesterday, several large tech companies joined Twitter in making their pandemic-imposed remote work arrangements more permanent. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/mark-zuckerberg-half-facebook-may-work-remotely-2030-n1212081?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">announced in his weekly livestream</a> with employees that the company’s 45,000+ person workforce will move toward a more remote system. Zuckerberg estimated Facebook will be up to half remote within the next 10 years. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The details: </strong>In the near term, Facebook will dial up remote recruiting and hiring; new recruits to U.S. roles will be given the option to work remotely. Eventually, existing employees will be able to request a permanent WFH setup (we recommend a <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/13/essentials-issue-4-dirty?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">vertical mouse</a>). </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>95% of Facebook employees are working remotely right now, and Zuckerberg only expects about 25% to be back in the office by the end of the year. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>If you’re still in your sorority’s group chat, Facebook wants you in the office. Recent college grads will have to clock in while they're getting started. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The reasoning: </strong>Zuck told The Verge’s Casey Newton that work on “<a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/5/21/21265780/facebook-remote-work-mark-zuckerberg-interview-wfh?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">remote presence</a>” products like Portal and Facebook Workplace gave execs a growing sense that distributed working was doable. And then COVID-19 made distributed working necessary. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>...and this may allow Facebook to scale back pay. If employees leave the Bay Area and relocate to virtually anywhere but Tribeca or Monaco, their cost of living will drop. And Zuckerberg </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/21/zuckerberg-50percent-of-facebook-employees-could-be-working-remotely.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">will adjust</a></span><span> compensation accordingly. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">There’s something in the air</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Spotify and Shopify made their own “we’re going flexible” statements yesterday, too. Spotify’s global workforce can WFH until next year, and Shopify’s will be allowed to do so as long as they please—a “forever” policy à la Twitter. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The biz world has set sail toward Remote Work Isle, but it’s a <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/silicon-valleys-next-big-office-idea-work-from-anywhere-11589740234?mod=article_inline&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">much easier journey</a> for high-income, plugged-in tech workers. 67% of respondents to our <a href="https://twitter.com/MorningBrew/status/1263497563426246657?s=20&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">unofficial Twitter poll</a> said they expect to be back in the office by the end of the year.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/21/hbo-max-launches-next-wednesday?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
HBO's Ready to Max Out
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Justice league " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMDU5L2p1c3RpY2VfbGVhZ3VlLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>WarnerMedia</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Streaming service HBO Max will be the crown jewel of AT&T’s entertainment empire when it launches Wednesday. But don’t <a href="https://www.hbo.com/hbo-news/hbo-max-hbo-go-hbo-now-difference?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">confuse</a> it with…</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>HBO, the channel</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>HBO Go, the streaming service offered through cable/TV providers</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>HBO Now, the standalone streaming service (most Now subscribers can convert to Max for free)</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s more confusing than Spotify/Shopify, which means AT&T’s WarnerMedia has an <a href="https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/business/story/2020-05-21/hbo-max-streaming-marketing-coronavirus-warner-media?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">uphill battle</a> proving HBO Max is worth $15/month. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What it’s got</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Signature HBO programming, new originals, the Warner Bros. library, a <em>Friends </em>reunion, and... </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The <a href="https://link.nbcnews.com/view/57c09634487ccd31218b6128c4sbm.4km/d67397fe?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">exclusive release</a> of director Zach Snyder’s never-seen cut of <em>Justice League</em>. Never seen because...never made. Warner Bros. will drop up to $30 million finishing his original vision, which will be released next year. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The “Snyder Cut” demonstrates the value of IP for entertainment brands. Even if it’s worse than the original, it might not matter because DC comic fans will come, per NBC’s Dylan Byers.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While HBO's throwing money around, how about a new final season of <em>GOT</em>?</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/21/atlantic-becomes-latest-publisher-layoff-employees?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Bad News for News News
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="News" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMDU4L25ld3MucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Atlantic has been widely praised for breakthrough COVID-19 coverage. But yesterday, the magazine <a href="https://www.axios.com/the-atlantic-layoffs-coronavirus-49cc6ad2-6579-45cd-b816-e20865f7351e.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">announced</a> it was laying off 17% of staff following cuts at other digital media companies like BuzzFeed, Vice, and Quartz.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The pandemic has created a textbook case of situational irony. Many media companies are experiencing <a href="https://medium.com/the-idea/covid-19-media-factsheet-35329ff75cb2?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">huge bumps</a> in subscriptions and visitors; The Atlantic has signed up 90,000 paying subscribers since March. Yet a collapse in ad revenue crashed the party before the pregame could start.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Few have been spared </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Layoffs, furloughs, and pay cuts have <a href="https://www.poynter.org/business-work/2020/here-are-the-newsroom-layoffs-furloughs-and-closures-caused-by-the-coronavirus/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">made their way</a> across newspapers, magazines, radio, TV, and digital media. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yes, many in digital media were hurting before the pandemic due to an <a href="https://twitter.com/studyhallxyz/status/1263470936986132483?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">overreliance</a> on venture capital and advertising competition from Facebook and Google. But the pandemic shocked not only their core revenue stream (advertising), but also events and B2B offerings. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here:</strong> Staffers at The LA Times created a “<a href="https://deezlinks.substack.com/p/deez-interviews-matt-pearce-on-everything?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">work share</a>” program, where employees reduce hours and collect partial unemployment. Some experts think such arrangements could present a more cost-effective alternative to layoffs.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
AUTOMATION
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/21/retailers-turn-automation-efficiency-safety-coronavirus-pandemic?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Retailers Find Relief in Robots
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Robot taking off from Earth" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC84OTUvcm9ib3RfdGFraW5nX29mZl9mcm9tX2VhcnRoLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Recently, Gap Inc.’s SVP of global logistics fulfillment called robotics firm Kindred AI with an unusual request. We don’t have the transcript, but <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-gap-automation-foc/gap-rushes-in-more-robots-to-warehouses-to-solve-virus-disruption-idUSKBN22X14Y?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Reuters reports</a> he asked something to the effect of, “I know you planned to deliver those robots in a few months, but could you do it...nowish?” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>With the pandemic bearing down, Gap warehouses were forced to do more with less. It wasn’t safe to operate distribution centers with a full staff, and the company had to process a surge in online orders. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>The pandemic is giving retailers a new reason to employ robotics tech that has graduated from moving items across floors to more sophisticated tasks, like box packing and cashier functions. Walmart, Amazon, and many grocery chains have ramped up their automated operations in recent months to keep up with demand. As Retail Brew Writer <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/04/08/retailers-embrace-emerging-technologies-due-covid19?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Halie LeSavage puts it</a>, robots don’t cough. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Happy ending: </strong>Kindred got 10 machines to a Gap warehouse in Tennessee and 20 to one in Ohio.</p>

PODCAST
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/21/morning-brews-business-casual-podcast-breaks-biggest-questions-business?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Look Out, Joe Rogan
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

</table>
<img alt="Business Casual logo " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNTEvYnVzaW5lc3NfY2FzdWFsX2xvZ28uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On our podcast, <em>Business Casual</em>, host Kinsey Grant asks the biggest names in business to answer the biggest questions in business. We know that’s a...big ask, but <em>Business Casual</em> guests deliver. Here are some recent episodes worth checking out:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><em>Shark Tank </em></span><span>legend Barbara Corcoran breaks down everything you’ve ever wanted to know about </span><span><a href="https://www.businesscasual.fm/barbara-corcoran-on-the-emotional-economics-of-the-housing-market/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">residential</a></span><span> and </span><span><a href="http://businesscasual.fm/latest?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">commercial</a></span><span> real estate.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Can capitalism survive—and better yet, should it? VC </span><span><a href="https://www.businesscasual.fm/can-capitalism-survive-chamath-palihapitiya-isnt-sure/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Chamath Palihapitiya</a></span><span> shares his controversial response.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Billionaire hedge fund manager </span><span><a href="https://www.businesscasual.fm/ray-dalio-predicting-our-future-using-our-past/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ray Dalio</a></span><span> explains why studying business = studying history.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>And a classic from the pre-COVID archives: </span><span><a href="https://www.businesscasual.fm/hard-work-or-nothing-gary-vaynerchuk-gets-candid/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Gary Vaynerchuk</a></span><span> on hard work, success, and selling baseball cards.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Got an idea for a future episode? Want to hear what Mark Cuban is like off the record? Take it up with Kinsey <a href="https://twitter.com/KinseyGrant?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">on Twitter</a>.</p>

Real winners can listen to podcasts and play cards at the same time.</p>

<tr>

style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nGrandma, What’s a Commute?\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Home office\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC85MzMvaG9tZV9vZmZpY2UuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOne day, you might compare working in an office to remembering someone's phone number—something you don't have to do anymore. Yesterday, several large tech companies joined Twitter in making their pandemic-imposed remote work arrangements more permanent. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFacebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/mark-zuckerberg-half-facebook-may-work-remotely-2030-n1212081?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eannounced in his weekly livestream\u003c/a\u003e with employees that the company’s 45,000+ person workforce will move toward a more remote system. Zuckerberg estimated Facebook will be up to half remote within the next 10 years. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe details: \u003c/strong\u003eIn the near term, Facebook will dial up remote recruiting and hiring; new recruits to U.S. roles will be given the option to work remotely. Eventually, existing employees will be able to request a permanent WFH setup (we recommend a \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/13/essentials-issue-4-dirty?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003evertical mouse\u003c/a\u003e). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e95% of Facebook employees are working remotely right now, and Zuckerberg only expects about 25% to be back in the office by the end of the year. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIf you’re still in your sorority’s group chat, Facebook wants you in the office. Recent college grads will have to clock in while they're getting started. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe reasoning: \u003c/strong\u003eZuck told The Verge’s Casey Newton that work on “\u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/5/21/21265780/facebook-remote-work-mark-zuckerberg-interview-wfh?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eremote presence\u003c/a\u003e” products like Portal and Facebook Workplace gave execs a growing sense that distributed working was doable. And then COVID-19 made distributed working necessary. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e...and this may allow Facebook to scale back pay. If employees leave the Bay Area and relocate to virtually anywhere but Tribeca or Monaco, their cost of living will drop. And Zuckerberg \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/21/zuckerberg-50percent-of-facebook-employees-could-be-working-remotely.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewill adjust\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e compensation accordingly. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThere’s something in the air\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSpotify and Shopify made their own “we’re going flexible” statements yesterday, too. Spotify’s global workforce can WFH until next year, and Shopify’s will be allowed to do so as long as they please—a “forever” policy à la Twitter. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe biz world has set sail toward Remote Work Isle, but it’s a \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/silicon-valleys-next-big-office-idea-work-from-anywhere-11589740234?mod=article_inline\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emuch easier journey\u003c/a\u003e for high-income, plugged-in tech workers. 67% of respondents to our \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/MorningBrew/status/1263497563426246657?s=20\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eunofficial Twitter poll\u003c/a\u003e said they expect to be back in the office by the end of the year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F05%2F21%2Ffacebook-joins-accelerating-trend-toward-permanent-remote-work\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block; Warner Bros. will drop up to $30 million finishing his original vision, which will be released next year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe “Snyder Cut” demonstrates the value of IP for entertainment brands. Even if it’s worse than the original, it might not matter because DC comic fans will come, per NBC’s Dylan Byers.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhile HBO's throwing money around, how about a new final season of \u003cem\u003eGOT\u003c/em\u003e?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F05%2F21%2Fhbo-max-launches-next-wednesday\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMDU4L25ld3MucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Atlantic has been widely praised for breakthrough COVID-19 coverage. But yesterday, the magazine \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/the-atlantic-layoffs-coronavirus-49cc6ad2-6579-45cd-b816-e20865f7351e.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eannounced\u003c/a\u003e it was laying off 17% of staff following cuts at other digital media companies like BuzzFeed, Vice, and Quartz.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe pandemic has created a textbook case of situational irony. Many media companies are experiencing \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/the-idea/covid-19-media-factsheet-35329ff75cb2?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehuge bumps\u003c/a\u003e in subscriptions and visitors; The Atlantic has signed up 90,000 paying subscribers since March. Yet a collapse in ad revenue crashed the party before the pregame could start.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eFew have been spared \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLayoffs, furloughs, and pay cuts have \u003ca href=\"https://www.poynter.org/business-work/2020/here-are-the-newsroom-layoffs-furloughs-and-closures-caused-by-the-coronavirus/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emade their way\u003c/a\u003e across newspapers, magazines, radio, TV, and digital media. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYes, many in digital media were hurting before the pandemic due to an \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/studyhallxyz/status/1263470936986132483?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eoverreliance\u003c/a\u003e on venture capital and advertising competition from Facebook and Google. But the pandemic shocked not only their core revenue stream (advertising), but also events and B2B offerings. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ While we’re here:\u003c/strong\u003e Staffers at The LA Times created a “\u003ca href=\"https://deezlinks.substack.com/p/deez-interviews-matt-pearce-on-everything?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ework share\u003c/a\u003e” program, where employees reduce hours and collect partial unemployment. Some experts think such arrangements could present a more cost-effective alternative to layoffs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eRecently, Gap Inc.’s SVP of global logistics fulfillment called robotics firm Kindred AI with an unusual request. We don’t have the transcript, but \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-gap-automation-foc/gap-rushes-in-more-robots-to-warehouses-to-solve-virus-disruption-idUSKBN22X14Y?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eReuters reports\u003c/a\u003e he asked something to the effect of, “I know you planned to deliver those robots in a few months, but could you do it...nowish?” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eWith the pandemic bearing down, Gap warehouses were forced to do more with less. It wasn’t safe to operate distribution centers with a full staff, and the company had to process a surge in online orders. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThe pandemic is giving retailers a new reason to employ robotics tech that has graduated from moving items across floors to more sophisticated tasks, like box packing and cashier functions. Walmart, Amazon, and many grocery chains have ramped up their automated operations in recent months to keep up with demand. As Retail Brew Writer \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/04/08/retailers-embrace-emerging-technologies-due-covid19?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eHalie LeSavage puts it\u003c/a\u003e, robots don’t cough. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHappy ending: \u003c/strong\u003eKindred got 10 machines to a Gap warehouse in Tennessee and 20 to one in Ohio.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F05%2F21%2Fretailers-turn-automation-efficiency-safety-coronavirus-pandemic\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block;
